rules.rule_text_en: Use each or every to talk about all members of a group. Each focuses on members one by one; every gives a general idea.
rules.rule_text_uk: Використовуйте each або every, коли говорите про всіх у групі. Each підкреслює кожного окремо, а every — загальну ідею.
rules.rule_short_en: each/every = all in a group (focus differs)
examples: Each student has a locker.
I check my email every morning.
Each of the lights was on.
Every seat was taken.

rules.rule_text_en: Use each of + plural noun/pronoun (each of the students / each of them). With every, use every one of, not *every of*.
rules.rule_text_uk: Використовуйте each of + множину (each of the students / each of them). З every вживають every one of, а не *every of*.
examples: Each of my friends lives in a different city.
Every one of these keys is important.
Each of them agreed.
Every one of the rooms was clean.

rules.rule_text_en: Each can go after the noun or at the end: two tickets each / They cost €5 each.
rules.rule_text_uk: Each може стояти після іменника або в кінці: two tickets each / They cost €5 each.
rules.rule_short_en: each can come at the end
examples: The apples are 30 cents each.
We were given a badge each.
They got two days off each.
The coffees cost €3 each.

rules.rule_text_en: Everyone (everybody) means ‘all people’. Every one means ‘each single person/thing’ (two words).
rules.rule_text_uk: Everyone (everybody) означає «усі люди». Every one означає «кожен окремий» (два слова).
rules.rule_short_en: everyone = all people; every one = each single
rules.rule_short_uk: everyone = усі люди; every one = кожен окремий
examples: Everyone knows that street.
Every one of the answers was wrong.
Everyone was invited.
Every one of the candles went out.

rules.rule_text_en: A relative clause tells you which person or thing we mean, or adds information about it.
rules.rule_text_uk: Підрядне означальне речення (relative clause) уточнює, про яку людину/річ ідеться, або додає про неї інформацію.
rules.rule_short_en: Relative clause = extra info about a noun
rules.rule_short_uk: Relative clause = додаткова інформація про іменник
examples: That’s the man who helped me.
This is the book that changed my mind.
I met a woman who works with my sister.

rules.rule_text_en: For people, use who (or that) in defining relative clauses. Don’t repeat he/she/they.
rules.rule_text_uk: Про людей у означальних підрядних зазвичай кажуть who (або that). Не повторюйте he/she/they.
examples: The girl who called you is here.
I like people that make me laugh.
The man who lives upstairs is a pilot.

rules.rule_text_en: For things, use which (or that) in defining relative clauses. Don’t repeat it/they.
rules.rule_text_uk: Про речі в означальних підрядних кажуть which (або that). Не повторюйте it/they.
examples: Where’s the phone which was on the table?
I need a tool that cuts metal.
The movie which we watched was long.

rules.rule_text_en: What means ‘the thing(s) that’. We use what without a noun before it.
rules.rule_text_uk: What означає «те, що / те, що саме». What вживаємо без іменника перед ним.
examples: I don’t understand what you mean.
Tell me what happened.
What she said surprised me.

rules.rule_text_en: If the relative pronoun is the subject of the clause, you must use who/that/which.
rules.rule_text_uk: Якщо відносний займенник є підметом у підрядному, його не можна пропускати: who/that/which потрібні.
examples: The people who live next door are friendly.
I lost the key that opens this door.
It was a song which made me cry.

rules.rule_text_en: If the relative pronoun is the object, you can often leave it out (especially in spoken English).
rules.rule_text_uk: Якщо відносний займенник є додатком, його часто можна опустити (особливо в розмовній мові).
examples: The book (that) I bought is great.
The person (who) you met is my boss.
The film (which) we saw was funny.

rules.rule_text_en: With prepositions, the preposition often goes at the end: the man I spoke to. (Formal: to whom / in which.)
rules.rule_text_uk: З прийменниками прийменник часто стоїть в кінці: the man I spoke to. (Офіційно: to whom / in which.)
examples: This is the chair I sat on.
She’s the colleague I work with.
Is that the hotel you stayed at?

rules.rule_text_en: Use that (not what) after words like everything/all/something. Use what when it means ‘the thing(s) that’.
rules.rule_text_uk: Після everything/all/something вживайте that (не what). What використовують у значенні «те, що».
rules.rule_short_en: everything/all + that; what = the thing that
examples: Everything that he said was true.
I took all (that) I needed.
What you did was brave.

rules.rule_text_en: Whose shows possession in a relative clause: the woman whose car was stolen.
rules.rule_text_uk: Whose показує належність у відносному реченні: the woman whose car was stolen.
examples: I know a man whose sister is a lawyer.
That’s the house whose roof is red.
She met a girl whose phone was broken.

rules.rule_text_en: Whom is the object form for people (formal). In everyday English, we often use who or omit it.
rules.rule_text_uk: Whom — обʼєктна форма для людей (офіційно). У звичайній мові часто вживають who або опускають займенник.
examples: The man whom I saw was angry.
Who did you speak to? (informal)
The person (whom) I called didn’t answer.

rules.rule_text_en: Where can mean ‘in/at/to which’ for places: the restaurant where we met.
rules.rule_text_uk: Where може означати «в/на/куди» для місць: the restaurant where we met.
examples: That’s the park where I learned to ride.
Is this the desk where you work?
We visited the town where my parents met.

rules.rule_text_en: For time/reason words, use that/which/when/why: the day (that) we arrived, the reason (why) I left.
rules.rule_text_uk: Для часу/причини вживають that/which/when/why: the day (that) we arrived, the reason (why) I left.
examples: I remember the day (that) we moved.
Tell me the reason (why) you’re late.
That was the moment when I decided.

rules.rule_text_en: There are two kinds of relative clause: defining (it tells which one) and non-defining (extra information).
rules.rule_text_uk: Є два типи означальних підрядних: визначальні (уточнюють який саме) і невизначальні (додають інформацію).
examples: The man who lives next door is a doctor. (defining)
My brother, who lives in Canada, is visiting. (non-defining)

rules.rule_text_en: Non-defining clauses use commas. You can’t use that, and you can’t omit who/which/whose.
rules.rule_text_uk: Невизначальні підрядні виділяються комами. Не використовують that і не опускають who/which/whose.
rules.rule_short_en: Type 2: commas; no that; no omission
rules.rule_short_uk: Тип 2: коми; без that; не опускати
examples: Sarah, who works with me, is on holiday.
This book, which I bought yesterday, is expensive.
Mr Lee, whose office is upstairs, called.

rules.rule_text_en: Non-defining clauses can refer to a whole clause with which: He missed the train, which annoyed him.
rules.rule_text_uk: У невизначальних підрядних which може посилатися на всю думку: He missed the train, which annoyed him.
rules.rule_short_en: which can refer to the whole clause
examples: He forgot my birthday, which upset me.
We changed the plan, which was a relief.
She apologised, which surprised me.

rules.rule_text_en: In non-defining clauses, a preposition can come before whom/which (formal): to whom, for which.
rules.rule_text_uk: У невизначальних підрядних прийменник може стояти перед whom/which (офіційно): to whom, for which.
examples: Mr Jones, to whom I wrote, replied quickly.
The company, for which she works, is international.
The house, in which they lived, was old.

rules.rule_text_en: Use quantifiers + whom/which: all of whom, none of which, most of which, etc.
rules.rule_text_uk: Вживайте кількісні слова + whom/which: all of whom, none of which, most of which тощо.
examples: Ten students, all of whom passed, celebrated.
She has two cars, neither of which she uses.
We visited three museums, most of which were free.

rules.rule_text_en: Which (not what) can refer to a whole idea: He won again, which amazed us.
rules.rule_text_uk: Which (не what) може стосуватися всієї ситуації: He won again, which amazed us.
rules.rule_short_en: which refers to a whole idea
examples: He cancelled at the last minute, which was annoying.
They moved abroad, which I didn’t expect.
I lost my wallet, which was a disaster.

rules.rule_text_en: Use -ing clauses to describe someone/something doing an action: the woman talking to Tom.
rules.rule_text_uk: Вживайте -ing clauses, щоб описати людину/річ, яка виконує дію: the woman talking to Tom.
examples: The man waiting outside is my uncle.
We saw a dog chasing a cat.
I heard music coming from upstairs.

rules.rule_text_en: Use -ed clauses for passive meaning: the boy injured in the accident, the money stolen.
rules.rule_text_uk: Вживайте -ed clauses для пасивного значення: the boy injured in the accident, the money stolen.
examples: The documents signed yesterday are on my desk.
The bike stolen last week was found.
The cake made by Nina was delicious.

rules.rule_text_en: Use there is/was + -ing/-ed clauses to say what exists or was happening: There were children playing.
rules.rule_text_uk: Використовуйте there is/was + -ing/-ed clauses, щоб сказати, що є/було або що відбувалося: There were children playing.
examples: There was a car parked outside.
Is there anyone waiting?
There were birds singing in the trees.

rules.rule_text_en: -ing adjectives describe something that causes a feeling; -ed adjectives describe how someone feels.
rules.rule_text_uk: -ing прикметники описують те, що викликає відчуття; -ed прикметники описують, як хтось почувається.
examples: The lecture was boring.
I was bored after ten minutes.
It’s an exciting match.
She felt excited.

rules.rule_text_en: Many pairs follow this pattern (interested/interesting, embarrassed/embarrassing, tired/tiring). Choose the form by meaning.
rules.rule_text_uk: Багато пар працюють так само (interested/interesting, embarrassed/embarrassing, tired/tiring). Обирайте форму за значенням.
examples: It was a shocking story.
They were shocked by the news.
The job is tiring.
He’s tired after work.

rules.rule_text_en: Opinion adjectives usually come before fact adjectives: a lovely old house.
rules.rule_text_uk: Оцінні прикметники зазвичай стоять перед фактичними: a lovely old house.
examples: a beautiful large garden
a horrible little mistake
a nice new coat

rules.rule_text_en: Typical order for fact adjectives is: size → age → shape → colour → origin → material → purpose.
rules.rule_text_uk: Типовий порядок фактичних прикметників: розмір → вік → форма → колір → походження → матеріал → призначення.
examples: a small round wooden table
a big old black leather bag
a new Italian sports car

rules.rule_text_en: Use adjectives after be/look/feel/seem etc. Use adverbs to say how you do something: drive carefully.
rules.rule_text_uk: Після be/look/feel/seem тощо вживають прикметники. Прислівники описують, як ви робите дію: drive carefully.
rules.rule_short_en: adjective after be/look; adverb with actions
rules.rule_short_uk: прикм. після be/look; присл. з діями
examples: You look tired.
She spoke politely.
The soup tastes wonderful.
He ran quickly.

rules.rule_text_en: With first/next/last + a number, the number comes after: the first two days, the next few weeks.
rules.rule_text_uk: З first/next/last + числом число стоїть після: the first two days, the next few weeks.
rules.rule_short_en: the first two / the next few / the last three
rules.rule_short_uk: the first two / the next few / the last three
examples: the first three questions
the next ten minutes
the last two chapters

rules.rule_text_en: Many adverbs end in -ly (slowly), but some -ly words are adjectives (friendly, lovely).
rules.rule_text_uk: Багато прислівників закінчуються на -ly (slowly), але деякі -ly слова — прикметники (friendly, lovely).
examples: He spoke quietly.
She smiled happily.
It was a friendly chat.

rules.rule_text_en: Adjectives describe nouns; adverbs describe verbs or whole actions. Some words have different forms: good/well.
rules.rule_text_uk: Прикметники описують іменники; прислівники описують дію. Деякі слова мають різні форми: good/well.
examples: She is a good driver.
She drives well.
The exam was easy.
I did easily the best.

rules.rule_text_en: Use adjectives after be/look/feel/sound etc, but use adverbs after action verbs: speak quietly, work hard.
rules.rule_text_uk: Після be/look/feel/sound тощо — прикметник; після дієслів дії — прислівник: speak quietly, work hard.
examples: I feel happy.
He laughed loudly.
The music sounds terrible.
She sang beautifully.

rules.rule_text_en: Adverbs can modify adjectives/adverbs and past participles: really tired, terribly sorry, badly damaged.
rules.rule_text_uk: Прислівники можуть підсилювати прикметники/прислівники та дієприкметники: really tired, terribly sorry, badly damaged.
examples: I’m extremely sorry.
The building was badly damaged.
She was incredibly kind.
